heading: Births
txt: Charles Kingsley, English priest, historian, and author (d. 1875)

entities.title: Charles Kingsley
entities.description: Charles Kingsley was a broad church priest of the Church of England, a university professor, social reformer, historian, novelist and poet. He is particularly associated with Christian socialism, the working men's college, and forming labour cooperatives, which failed, but encouraged later working reforms. He was a friend and correspondent of Charles Darwin.

heading: Births
txt: Johanna Spyri, Swiss author, best known for Heidi (d. 1901)

entities.title: Johanna Spyri
entities.description: Johanna Louise Spyri was a Swiss author of novels, notably children's stories, and is best known for her book Heidi. Born in Hirzel, a rural area in the canton of Zurich, Switzerland, as a child she spent several summers near Chur in Graubünden, the setting she later would use in her novels.

entities.title: Heidi
entities.description:
Heidi is a work of children's fiction published in 1881 by Swiss author Johanna Spyri, originally published in two parts as Heidi: Her Years of Wandering and Learning and Heidi: How She Used What She Learned .
It is a novel about the events in the life of a 5-year-old girl in her paternal grandfather's care in the Swiss Alps. It was written as a book "for children and those who love children".

heading: Births
txt: Robert Herbert, English-Australian politician, 1st Premier of Queensland (d. 1905)

entities.title: Robert Herbert
entities.description: Sir Robert George Wyndham Herbert,, was the first Premier of Queensland, Australia. At 28 years and 181 days of age, he was the youngest person to ever be elected Premier of an Australian state.

entities.title: Premier of Queensland
entities.description: The Premier of Queensland is the head of government in the Australian state of Queensland.

heading: Births
txt: Watson Fothergill, English architect, designed the Woodborough Road Baptist Church (d. 1928)

entities.title: Watson Fothergill
entities.description: Watson Fothergill was a British architect who designed over 100 unique buildings in Nottingham in the East Midlands of England, his influences were mainly from the Gothic Revival and Old English vernacular architecture styles.

entities.title: Woodborough Road Baptist Church
entities.description: Woodborough Road Baptist Church is a former Baptist Church on Woodborough Road in Nottingham. It is a Grade II listed building. It was converted around 1980 and after being run as the Pakistani League of Friends, is now an Pakistan Community Centre.

entities.title: David Gill (astronomer)
entities.description: Sir David Gill was a Scottish astronomer who is known for measuring astronomical distances, for astrophotography, and for geodesy. He spent much of his career in South Africa.

txt: Oliver Lodge, English physicist and academic (d. 1940)

entities.title: Oliver Lodge
entities.description: Sir Oliver Joseph Lodge, was a British physicist and writer involved in the development of, and holder of key patents for, radio. He identified electromagnetic radiation independent of Hertz's proof and at his 1894 Royal Institution lectures, Lodge demonstrated an early radio wave detector he named the "coherer". In 1898 he was awarded the "syntonic" patent by the United States Patent Office. Lodg

txt: Harry Johnston, English botanist and explorer (d. 1927)

entities.title: Harry Johnston
entities.description: Sir Henry Hamilton Johnston, known as Harry Johnston, was a British explorer, botanist, artist, colonial administrator, and linguist who traveled widely in Africa and spoke many African languages. He published 40 books on African subjects and was one of the key players in the Scramble for Africa that occurred at the end of the 19th century.

Attewell was a medium pace bowler who was renowned for his extraordinary accuracy and economy. entities.title: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
entities.description: The prime minister of the United Kingdom is the head of government in the United Kingdom. The term has been widely used to denote a "commander", "general", or "leader" i.e. Amir al-Mu'min. The feminine form is emira. When translated as "prince

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Leo III (b. 750)

entities.title: Pope Leo III
entities.description: Pope Leo III was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from 26 December 795 to his death. Protected by Charlemagne from the supporters of his predecessor, Adrian I, Leo subsequently strengthened Charlemagne's position by crowning him emperor. The coronation was not approved in Constantinople, although the Byzantines, occupied with their own defenses, were in no position to offer much op

heading: Deaths
txt: Æthelflæd, Mercian daughter of Alfred the Great (b. 870)

entities.title: Æthelflæd
entities.description: Æthelflæd, Lady of the Mercians ruled Mercia in the English Midlands from 911 until her death. She was the eldest daughter of Alfred the Great, king of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Wessex, and his wife Ealhswith.

entities.title: Alfred the Great
entities.description: Alfred the Great was king of the West Saxons from 871 to c. 886 and king of the Anglo-Saxons from c. 886 to 899. He was the youngest son of King Æthelwulf, who died when Alfred was young. Three of Alfred's brothers, Æthelbald, Æthelberht and Æthelred, reigned in turn before him.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lyfing, English archbishop (b. 999)

entities.title: Lyfing (Archbishop of Canterbury)
entities.description: Lyfing was an Anglo-Saxon Bishop of Wells and Archbishop of Canterbury.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tedald, Italian bishop (b. 990)

entities.title: Tedald (bishop of Arezzo)
entities.description: Tedald, also known as Theodald, Theodaldus, Tedaldus, Tedaldo, or Teodaldo, was the forty-third Bishop of Arezzo from 1023 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Al-Zamakhshari, Persian theologian (b. 1075)

entities.title: Al-Zamakhshari
entities.description: Abū al-Qāsim Maḥmūd ibn Umar al-Zamakhsharī, known as al-Zamakhsharī, or Jar Allāh, was a medieval Muslim scholar of Persian origin. He was a great Hanafite jurist, Mu'tazilite theologian and authority on Arabic language philology. Al-Zamakhshari's fame as a scholar rests upon his tafsir (exegesis) in his commentary on the Qur'an, Al-Kashshaaf. This seminal philosophical linguistic analysis of Qur

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry of Scotland, 3rd Earl of Huntingdon (b. 1114)

entities.title: Henry of Scotland
entities.description: Henry of Scotland was heir apparent to the Kingdom of Alba. He was also the 3rd Earl of Northumberland and the 3rd Earl of Huntingdon. He was the son of King David I of Scotland and Queen Maud, 2nd Countess of Huntingdon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry II, Prince of Anhalt-Aschersleben (b. 1215)

entities.title: Henry II, Prince of Anhalt-Aschersleben
entities.description: Henry II, Prince of Anhalt-Aschersleben was a German prince of the House of Ascania and ruler of the principality of Anhalt-Aschersleben.

heading: Deaths
txt: John I of Brienne, Count of Eu

entities.title: John I of Brienne, Count of Eu
entities.description: John I of Brienne was the son of Alphonso of Brienne and Marie de Lusigan. His mother was the heiress of Eu, Seine-Maritime, and he succeeded his father as Count of Eu in 1270.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard VII, Count of Armagnac (b. 1360)

entities.title: Bernard VII, Count of Armagnac
entities.description: Bernard VII, Count of Armagnac was Count of Armagnac and Constable of France. He was the son of John II and Jeanne de Périgord. He succeeded in Armagnac at the death of his brother, John III, in 1391. After prolonged fighting, he also became Count of Comminges in 1412.

heading: Deaths
txt: John FitzAlan, 14th Earl of Arundel, English commander (b. 1408)

entities.title: John FitzAlan, 14th Earl of Arundel
entities.description: John Fitzalan, 7th Earl of Arundel, 4th Baron Maltravers KG was an English nobleman and military commander during the later phases of the Hundred Years' War. His father, John Fitzalan, 3rd Baron Maltravers, fought a long battle to lay claim to the Arundel earldom, a battle that was not finally resolved until after the father's death, when John Fitzalan the son was finally confirmed in the title in

heading: Deaths
txt: Ludovico III Gonzaga, Marquis of Mantua (b. 1412)

entities.title: Ludovico III Gonzaga, Marquis of Mantua
entities.description: Ludovico III Gonzaga of Mantua, also spelled Lodovico was the ruler of the Italian city of Mantua from 1444 to his death in 1478.

heading: Deaths
txt: Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar, Spanish conquistador (b. 1465)

entities.title: Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar
entities.description: Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar was a Spanish conquistador and the first governor of Cuba. In 1511 he led the successful conquest and colonization of Cuba. As the first governor of the island, he established several municipalities that remain important to this day and positioned Cuba as a center of trade and a staging point for expeditions of conquest elsewhere. From Cuba he chartered important expedit

heading: Deaths
txt: Ii Naomori, Japanese warrior (b. 1506)

entities.title: Ii Naomori
entities.description: Ii Naomori  was a retainer of the Japanese Imagawa clan during the Sengoku period of the 16th century. During the Battle of Okehazama in 1560, Naomori was killed while trying to protect his lord, Imagawa Yoshimoto during the attack led by Oda Nobunaga, who surprised his enemy when he attacked in thick fog following a hard rain. His childhood name was Toramatsu (虎松).

heading: Deaths
txt: Imagawa Yoshimoto, Japanese daimyō (b. 1519)

heading: Deaths
txt: Adrianus Turnebus, French philologist and scholar (b. 1512)

entities.title: Adrianus Turnebus
entities.description: Adrianus Turnebus was a French classical scholar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich, English politician, Lord Chancellor of England (b. 1490)

entities.title: Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich
entities.description: Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich, was Lord Chancellor during King Edward VI of England's reign, from 1547 until January 1552. He was the founder of Felsted School with its associated alms houses in Essex in 1564. He was a beneficiary of the Dissolution of the Monasteries, and persecuted opponents of church and state. He personally tortured the English writer, poet and Protestant martyr Anne Askew.

entities.title: Lord Chancellor
entities.description: The Lord Chancellor, formally the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, is the highest-ranking among the Great Officers of State who are appointed regularly in the United Kingdom, nominally outranking the Prime Minister. The Lord Chancellor is outranked only by the Lord High Steward, another Great Officer of State, who is appointed only for the day of coronations and to preside over impeachment t

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Farnaby, English scholar and educator (b. 1575)

entities.title: Thomas Farnaby
entities.description: Thomas Farnaby was an English schoolmaster and scholar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Berkeley, 2nd Viscount Fitzhardinge, English politician (b. 1599)

entities.title: Charles Berkeley, 2nd Viscount Fitzhardinge
entities.description: Charles Berkeley, 2nd Viscount Fitzhardinge was an English politician who sat in the House of Commons at various times between 1621 and 1668. He supported the Royalist cause in the English Civil War. He succeeded by special remainder to the peerage of his son who predeceased him.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Emmanuel II, Duke of Savoy (b. 1634)

entities.title: Charles Emmanuel II, Duke of Savoy
entities.description: Charles Emmanuel II ; 20 June 1634 – 12 June 1675) was the Duke of Savoy from 1638 to 1675 and under regency of his mother Christine of France until 1648. He was also Marquis of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Geneva, Moriana and Nice, as well as claimant king of Cyprus, Jerusalem and Armenia. At his death in 1675 his second wife Marie Jeanne Baptiste of Savoy-Nemours acted as Regent for their nine-year-

heading: Deaths
txt: James FitzJames, 1st Duke of Berwick, French-English general and politician, Lord Lieutenant of Hampshire (b. 1670)

entities.title: James FitzJames, 1st Duke of Berwick
entities.description: James FitzJames, 1st Duke of Berwick, 1st Duke of Liria and Jérica, 1st Duke of Fitz-James was an Anglo-French military leader, illegitimate son of King James II of England by Arabella Churchill, sister of the 1st Duke of Marlborough. Berwick was a successful general in the pay of Louis XIV of France.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Hampshire
entities.description: This is a list of people who have served as Lord Lieutenant of Hampshire. Since 1688, all the Lords Lieutenant have also been Custos Rotulorum of Hampshire. From 1889 until 1959, the administrative county was named the County of Southampton.

heading: Deaths
txt: Prince Augustus William of Prussia (b. 1722)

entities.title: Prince Augustus William of Prussia
entities.description: Augustus William of Prussia was Prince of Prussia and a younger brother and general of Frederick II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne, French explorer (b. 1724)

entities.title: Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne
entities.description: Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne, with the surname sometimes spelt Dufresne, was a Breton-born French explorer who made important discoveries in the south Indian Ocean, in Tasmania and in New Zealand. Du Fresne was killed by Māori in 1772.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip Livingston, American merchant and politician (b. 1716)

entities.title: Philip Livingston
entities.description: Philip Livingston was an American merchant and statesman from New York City. He represented New York at the October 1774 First Continental Congress, where he favored imposing economic sanctions upon Great Britain as a way of pressuring the British Parliament to repeal the Intolerable Acts. He was also a delegate to the Second Continental Congress from 1775 to 1778, and signed the Declaration of In

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Augereau, French general (b. 1757)

entities.title: Pierre Augereau
entities.description: Charles Pierre François Augereau, 1st Duke of Castiglione was a French military commander and a Marshal of the Empire who served during the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars. After serving in the Revolutionary Wars, he earned rapid promotion while fighting against Spain and soon found himself as a division commander under Napoleon Bonaparte in Italy. He fought in all of Bonaparte's

heading: Deaths
txt: Egwale Seyon, Ethiopian emperor

entities.title: Egwale Seyon
entities.description: Egwale Seyon or Gwalu (ጓሉ) was nəgusä nägäst of Ethiopia, and a member of the Solomonic dynasty. He was the son of Hezqeyas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantinos Nikolopoulos, Greek composer, archaeologist, and philologist (b. 1786)

entities.title: Konstantinos Nikolopoulos (composer)
entities.description: Konstantinos Agathophron Nikolopoulos was a Greek composer, philologist and colleague of Adamantios Korais.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lucretia Peabody Hale, American journalist and author (b. 1820)

entities.title: Lucretia Peabody Hale
entities.description: Lucretia Peabody Hale was an American journalist and author.

heading: Deaths
txt: Camille of Renesse-Breidbach (b. 1836)

entities.title: Camille of Renesse-Breidbach
entities.description: Camille Maximilien Frédéric, Count de Renesse-Breidbach was a Belgian nobleman, entrepreneur and author.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frédéric Passy, French economist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1822)

entities.title: Frédéric Passy
entities.description: Frédéric Passy was a French economist and pacifist who was a founding member of several peace societies and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. He was also an author and politician, sitting in the Chamber of Deputies from 1881 until 1889. He was a joint winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1901 for his work in the European peace movement.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Teresa Carreño, Venezuelan-American singer-songwriter, pianist, and conductor (b. 1853)

entities.title: Teresa Carreño
entities.description: María Teresa Gertrudis de Jesús Carreño García was a Venezuelan pianist, soprano, composer, and conductor. Over the course of her 54-year concert career, she became an internationally renowned virtuoso pianist and was often referred to as the "Valkyrie of the Piano". Carreño was an early adopter of the works of one of her students, American composer and pianist Edward MacDowell (1860–1908) and pre

heading: Deaths
txt: Theo Heemskerk, Dutch lawyer and politician, Prime Minister of the Netherlands (b. 1852)

entities.title: Theo Heemskerk
entities.description: Theodorus "Theo" Heemskerk was a Dutch politician of the Anti-Revolutionary Party (ARP) who served as Prime Minister of the Netherlands from 12 February 1908 until 29 August 1913.

entities.title: Prime Minister of the Netherlands
entities.description: The prime minister of the Netherlands is the head of the executive branch of the Government of the Netherlands. The prime minister is the chair of the Council of Ministers and coordinates its policy with his cabinet. The current acting prime minister is Mark Rutte, who serves in a demissionary capacity after his resignation on 15 January 2021.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mikhail Tukhachevsky, Russian general (b. 1893)

entities.title: Mikhail Tukhachevsky
entities.description: Mikhail Nikolayevich Tukhachevsky nicknamed Red Napoleon by foreign newspapers, was a leading Soviet military leader and theoretician from 1918 to 1937.

heading: Deaths
txt: Erich Marcks, German general (b. 1891)

entities.title: Erich Marcks
entities.description: Erich Marcks was a German general in the Wehrmacht during World War II. He authored the first draft of the operational plan, Operation Draft East, for Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union, advocating what was later known as A-A line as the goal for the Wehrmacht to achieve, within nine to seventeen weeks. Marcks studied philosophy in Freiburg in 1909.

heading: Deaths
txt: Médéric Martin, Canadian politician, mayor of Montreal (b. 1869)

entities.title: Médéric Martin
entities.description: Médéric Martin was a Canadian politician and long-time Mayor of Montreal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Lawson, Australian politician, 27th Premier of Victoria (b. 1875)

entities.title: Harry Lawson
entities.description: Sir Harry Sutherland Wightman Lawson KCMG, was an Australian politician who served as Premier of Victoria from 1918 to 1924. He later entered federal politics, serving as a Senator for Victoria (1929–1935) and briefly as a minister in the Lyons Government. He was a member of the Nationalist Party until 1931, when it was replaced with the United Australia Party.

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jimmy Dorsey, American saxophonist, composer, and bandleader (The Dorsey Brothers and The California Ramblers) (b. 1904)

entities.title: Jimmy Dorsey
entities.description: James Francis Dorsey, professionally known as Jimmy Dorsey, was an American jazz clarinetist, saxophonist, composer and big band leader. He recorded and composed the jazz and pop standards "I'm Glad There Is You " and "It's The Dreamer In Me". His other major recordings were "Tailspin", "John Silver", "So Many Times", "Amapola", "Brazil ", "Pennies from Heaven" with Bing Crosby, Louis Armstrong, a

entities.title: The Dorsey Brothers
entities.description: The Dorsey Brothers were an American studio dance band, led by Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey. They started recording in 1928 for OKeh Records.

entities.title: The California Ramblers
entities.description: The California Ramblers were an American jazz group that recorded hundreds of songs for many different record labels throughout the 1920s. Four members of the band – Red Nichols, Jimmy Dorsey, Tommy Dorsey, and Adrian Rollini – went on to front big bands in later decades.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Ireland, English composer and educator (b. 1879)

entities.title: John Ireland (composer)
entities.description: John Nicholson Ireland was an English composer and teacher of music. The majority of his output consists of piano miniatures and of songs with piano. His best-known works include the short instrumental or orchestral work "The Holy Boy", a setting of the poem "Sea-Fever" by John Masefield, a formerly much-played Piano Concerto, the hymn tune Love Unknown and the choral motet "Greater Love Hath No M

heading: Deaths
txt: Medgar Evers, American soldier and activist (b. 1925)

entities.title: Medgar Evers
entities.description: Medgar Wiley Evers was an American civil rights activist in Mississippi, the state's field secretary for the NAACP, and a World War II veteran who had served in the United States Army. He worked to overturn segregation at the University of Mississippi, end the segregation of public facilities, and expand opportunities for African Americans, which included the enforcement of voting rights.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hermann Scherchen, German viola player and conductor (b. 1891)

entities.title: Hermann Scherchen
entities.description: Hermann Scherchen was a German conductor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Read, English poet and critic (b. 1893)

entities.title: Herbert Read
entities.description: Sir Herbert Edward Read, was an English art historian, poet, literary critic and philosopher, best known for numerous books on art, which included influential volumes on the role of art in education. Read was co-founder of the Institute of Contemporary Arts. As well as being a prominent English anarchist, he was one of the earliest English writers to take notice of existentialism. He was co-editor

heading: Deaths
txt: Aleksandr Deyneka, Ukrainian-Russian painter and sculptor (b. 1899)

entities.title: Aleksandr Deyneka
entities.description: Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Deyneka was a Soviet Russian painter, graphic artist and sculptor, regarded as one of the most important Russian modernist figurative painters of the first half of the 20th century. His Collective Farmer on a Bicycle (1935) has been described as exemplifying the Socialist Realist style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmund Wilson, American critic, essayist, and editor (b. 1895)

entities.title: Edmund Wilson
entities.description: Edmund Wilson was an American writer and literary critic who explored Freudian and Marxist themes. He influenced many American authors, including F. Scott Fitzgerald, whose unfinished work he edited for publication. His scheme for a Library of America series of national classic works came to fruition through the efforts of Jason Epstein after Wilson's death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dinanath Gopal Tendulkar, Indian writer and documentary filmmaker (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gopinath Kaviraj, Indian philosopher and scholar (b. 1887)

entities.title: Gopinath Kaviraj
entities.description: Gopinath Kaviraj was an Indian Sanskrit scholar, Indologist and philosopher. First appointed in 1914 a librarian, he was the Principal of Government Sanskrit College, Varanasi from 1923 to 1937. He was also the editor of the Sarasvati Bhavana Granthamala during that period.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guo Moruo, Chinese historian, author, and poet (b. 1892)

entities.title: Guo Moruo
entities.description: Guo Moruo, courtesy name Dingtang (鼎堂), was a Chinese archaeologist, historian, poet, politician, and writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georg Siimenson, Estonian footballer (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy Butlin, South African-English businessman, founded the Butlins Company (b. 1899)

entities.title: Billy Butlin
entities.description: Sir William Heygate Edmund Colborne Butlin was a South African-born British entrepreneur whose name is synonymous with the British holiday camp. Although holiday camps such as Warner's existed in one form or another before Butlin opened his first in 1936, it was Butlin who turned holiday camps into a multimillion-pound industry and an important aspect of British culture.

entities.title: Butlins
entities.description: Butlin's is a chain of large seaside resorts in the United Kingdom. Butlin's was founded by Billy Butlin to provide affordable holidays for ordinary British families.

heading: Deaths
txt: Masayoshi Ōhira, Japanese politician, 68th Prime minister of Japan (b. 1910)

entities.title: Prime minister of Japan
entities.description: The prime minister of Japan  is head of the government of Japan, the chief executive of the National Cabinet and the commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Japan; he is appointed by the emperor of Japan after being designated by the National Diet and must enjoy the confidence of the House of Representatives to remain in office. He is the head of the Cabinet and appoints and dismisses the other

heading: Deaths
txt: Milburn Stone, American actor (b. 1904)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ian McKay, English sergeant, Victoria Cross recipient (b. 1953)

entities.title: Ian McKay
entities.description: Ian John McKay, VC was a British Army soldier and a posthumous recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

entities.title: Victoria Cross
entities.description: The Victoria Cross (VC) is the highest and most prestigious award of the British honours system. It is awarded for valour "in the presence of the enemy" to members of the British Armed Forces. It may be awarded posthumously. It was previously awarded to Commonwealth countries, most of which have established their own honours systems and no longer recommend British honours. It may be awarded to a p

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl von Frisch, Austrian-German ethologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1886)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Norma Shearer, Canadian-American actress (b. 1902)

entities.title: Norma Shearer
entities.description: Edith Norma Shearer was a Canadian-American actress who was active on film from 1919 through 1942. Shearer often played spunky, sexually liberated ingénues. She appeared in adaptations of Noël Coward, Eugene O'Neill, and William Shakespeare, and was the first five-time Academy Award acting nominee, winning Best Actress for The Divorcee (1930).

heading: Deaths
txt: Bruce Hamilton, Australian public servant (b. 1911)

entities.title: Bruce Hamilton (public servant)
entities.description: Leslie Bruce Hamilton was a senior Australian public servant and head of the Department of Social Services between 1966 and 1973.

heading: Deaths
txt: Terence O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of the Maine, English captain and politician, 4th Prime Minister of Northern Ireland (b. 1914)

entities.title: Terence O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of the Maine
entities.description: Terence Marne O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of the Maine, PC (NI), was the fourth Prime Minister of Northern Ireland and leader (1963–1969) of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP). A moderate unionist, who sought to reconcile the sectarian divisions in Northern Ireland society, he was Member of the Parliament of Northern Ireland for the Bannside constituency from 1946 until his resignation in January 1970; hi

entities.title: Prime Minister of Northern Ireland
entities.description: The Prime Minister of Northern Ireland was the head of the Government of Northern Ireland between 1921 and 1972. No such office was provided for in the Government of Ireland Act 1920; however, the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, as with governors-general in other Westminster Systems such as in Canada, chose to appoint someone to head the executive even though no such post existed in statute law. The o

heading: Deaths
txt: Menachem Mendel Schneerson, Russian-French rabbi and author (b. 1902)

entities.title: Menachem Mendel Schneerson
entities.description: Menachem Mendel Schneerson, known to many as the Lubavitcher Rebbe or simply the Rebbe, was a Russian-Empire-born American Orthodox rabbi, and the most recent rebbe of the Lubavitch Hasidic dynasty. He is considered one of the most influential Jewish leaders of the 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli, Italian pianist (b. 1920)

entities.title: Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli
entities.description: Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli was an Italian classical pianist. He is considered one of the greatest pianists of the twentieth century. According to The New York Times, he was perhaps the most reclusive, enigmatic and obsessive among the handful of the world's legendary pianists.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Russell, American basketball player (b. 1949)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bulat Okudzhava, Russian singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1924)

entities.title: Bulat Okudzhava
entities.description: Bulat Shalvovich Okudzhava was a Soviet and Russian poet, writer, musician, novelist, and singer-songwriter of Georgian-Armenian ancestry. He was one of the founders of the Soviet genre called "author song", or "guitar song", and the author of about 200 songs, set to his own poetry. His songs are a mixture of Russian poetic and folksong traditions and the French chansonnier style represented by su

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo Buscaglia, American author and educator (b. 1924)

entities.title: Leo Buscaglia
entities.description: Felice Leonardo Buscaglia, also known as "Dr. Love", was an American author, motivational speaker, and a professor in the Department of Special Education at the University of Southern California.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theresa Merritt, American actress and singer (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: J. F. Powers, American novelist and short story writer (b. 1917)

entities.title: J. F. Powers
entities.description: James Farl Powers was an American novelist and short story writer who often drew his inspiration from developments in the Catholic Church, and was known for his studies of Catholic priests in the Midwest. Although not a priest himself, he is known for having captured a "clerical idiom" in postwar North America. His first novel, Morte d'Urban, won the 1963 National Book Award for Fiction.

heading: Deaths
txt: Purushottam Laxman Deshpande, Indian actor, director, and producer (b. 1919)

entities.title: Purushottam Laxman Deshpande
entities.description: Purushottam Laxman Deshpande, popularly known by his initials or as P. L. Deshpande, was a Marathi writer and humorist from Maharashtra, India. He was also an accomplished film and stage actor, script writer, author, composer, musician, singer and orator. He was often referred to as "Maharashtra's beloved personality".

heading: Deaths
txt: Sandro Rosa do Nascimento, Brazilian criminal (b. 1978)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Blass, American fashion designer, founded Bill Blass Limited (b. 1922)

entities.title: Bill Blass
entities.description: William Ralph Blass was an American fashion designer, born in Fort Wayne, Indiana. He was the recipient of many fashion awards, including seven Coty Awards and the Fashion Institute of Technology's Lifetime Achievement Award (1999).

entities.title: Bill Blass Limited
entities.description: Bill Blass Group replaces what was formerly Bill Blass Limited, a fashion house founded by American designer Bill Blass.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zena Sutherland, American reviewer of children's literature (b. 1915)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gregory Peck, American actor and political activist (b. 1916)

entities.title: Gregory Peck
entities.description: Eldred Gregory Peck was an American actor. He was one of the most popular film stars from the 1940s to the 1960s. In 1999, the American Film Institute named Peck among 25 Greatest Male Stars of Classic Hollywood Cinema, ranking him at No. 12.

heading: Deaths
txt: Scott Young, Canadian journalist and author (b. 1918)

entities.title: Scott Young (writer)
entities.description: Scott Alexander Young was a Canadian journalist, sportswriter, novelist and the father of musicians Neil Young and Astrid Young. Over his career, Young wrote 45 books, including novels and non-fiction for adult and youth audiences.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicky Barr, Australian rugby player and fighter pilot (b. 1915)

entities.title: Nicky Barr
entities.description: Andrew William "Nicky" Barr, was a member of the Australian national rugby union team, who became a fighter ace in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) during World War II. He was credited with 12 aerial victories, all scored flying the Curtiss P-40 fighter. Born in New Zealand, Barr was raised in Victoria and first represented the state in rugby in 1936. Selected to play for Australia in the Uni

heading: Deaths
txt: György Ligeti, Romanian-Hungarian composer and educator (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenneth Thomson, 2nd Baron Thomson of Fleet, Canadian businessman and art collector (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: Miroslav Dvořák, Czech ice hockey player (b. 1951)

entities.title: Miroslav Dvořák (ice hockey)
entities.description: Miroslav Dvořák, nicknamed "Cookie", was a Czechoslovak professional ice hockey defenseman who played three seasons in the NHL with the Philadelphia Flyers. He is also well known as a famous player of Czech Extraliga (Czechoslovak) team HC České Budějovice, where he spent most of his active career.

heading: Deaths
txt: Derek Tapscott, Welsh footballer and manager (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: Al Williamson, American illustrator (b. 1931)

entities.title: Al Williamson
entities.description: Alfonso Williamson was an American cartoonist, comic book artist and illustrator specializing in adventure, Western and science fiction/fantasy.

heading: Deaths
txt: René Audet, Canadian bishop (b. 1920)

entities.title: The Coasters
entities.description: The Coasters are an American rhythm and blues/rock and roll vocal group who had a string of hits in the late 1950s. Beginning with "Searchin'" and "Young Blood", their most memorable songs were written by the songwriting and producing team of Leiber and Stoller. entities.title: Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences
entities.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, officially the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, is an economics prize administered by the Nobel Foundation. While it is not one of the Nobel Prizes, which were established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895, it is commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics. txt: Teresita Barajuen, Spanish nun (b. 1908)

entities.title: Teresita Barajuen
entities.description: Teresita Barajuen was a Spanish Roman Catholic nun and member of the Order of Cistercians. Barajuen is believed to hold the world record for the longest service in cloister.
